Actually, newer studies show that standing still may up one's risk of becoming puma chow. There was a study from the University of California, Davis, that looked at around 200 puma attacks from the last hundred years. The study also found, however, that those who ran had a slightly higher chance of being killed in an attack—28 percent of those who fled died as a result of injuries, compared with 23 percent of those who remained motionless during big cat attacks. About 39 percent who moved away slowly when approached by a mountain lion escaped without injury.

On the other hand, people who froze were the least likely to escape injury when a mountain lion attacked. Only 26 percent of them escaped. They also had the greatest frequency of severe injuries: 43 percent of those who stood still in the face of a lion were badly injured compared with 17 percent of those who fled, according to the study.

So the best combo is probably make yourself look big, shout, throw stuff, and back away slowly.

It was funny when Lara was quoting the semi-official, semi-cover story that various state and federal wildlife agencies have been using to avoid scaring city folk and suburbanites.  If you listen to the 4th minute section about their "re-expanding" range, she mentions them going into Iowa and Connecticut -- which are quite far apart.  I suspect she knows the northern populations are already in (and never disappeared from) Minnesota, Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, Pennsylvania, New York, etc; and the southeastern populations are also found from Florida to the Ohio River Valley and over to the Carolinas.  Also the Great Northern Forest lets them range across the continent and keep finding new opportunities where conditions allow... Canada does exist :)

Since pumas/cougars don't usually like to be close to human towns, wildlife/game officials basically bury reports of them and stick to the cover story if asked by the pop-press.  One state biologist I talked to said (approx), "Well, if we don't talk about it, it doesn't cause a public fuss."  This is mostly to protect the cougars, which are one of the few predators that can semi-control the white-tail deer overpopulation that spread lyme disease or end up starving in the winter, and so on.  For country people and farmers, cougars are a known part of the landscape and reduce the crop damage caused by the deer.  There just aren't enough human hunters to replace the traditional population controls that were formerly served by cougars and timber wolves.

In the long run, if we are going to preserve wild spaces and have balanced ecosystems, humans are going to have to learn to be responsible when going out to the wild lands or living in rural/forested areas.  That's the real news.  People need to be educated and equipped for co-existing with them.  Anywhere the woods meet the waters, there will be food for the big cats and a place for them in the chain of life.

Hank, a few years ago, a young male cougar met his unfortunate demise at the hands of the Chicago Police Department, after wandering all the way from South Dakota into a residential neighborhood on the north side if the city. I am glad to see this video. Many months ago (but less than a full year) I had a near encounter while hiking with my son. I didn't see it (didn't stick around) but I did hear it and since I spent a few years working with big cats(including a cougar) I was very familiar about the sounds they make.

 It was very close but in the woods off the main trail. I haven't been hiking since. I keep telling myself to get over it and go back but the main scare was worry for my son more than myself. At first I thought I was mistaken but upon contacting our local parks department and checking the website for the hiking areas I realized I was not mistaken.

The relationship Americans have with cougars seems similar to Finns and wolves. Wolves in Finland are even more endangered and kill even less people. They can be a threat to the property of some people raising reindeer, but wolves haven't caused any human deaths in Finland for over 120 years at this point. Most people will never have to deal with them and yet the fear of them is quite disproportional. I studied the changes in wolf population for a school paper some years back. The population is up a little and public image of wolves is a tad better as people are taking its endangerment more seriously, but it runs a serious risk of taking a hit if they become a little more common and sightings of wolves increase.
